content.description: Sit start the left-side of the overhang with a pinch on the arete and a shallow pocket for the right. Smack up to some slopers and figure out how to latch the incut crimp on the overhang. From here, slap to another left-hand pinch and figure out how to top-out.
content.location: This problem climbs the left overhanging arete of this boulder. This boulder is several hundred yards past "Skink, Skank, Skunk" for those using guidebooks.

content.description: Sit start with and aesthetic crescent-shaped left hand sidepull and another large undercling feature out right. Pick a foot and stand up to a good but blind crystal just over the lip. From here, some delicate foot work and some slopers get the climber into the crux mantle, and then a nice little slab to the top.
content.protection: The landing is slanted so pads tend to slide amongst the leaves. Putting a pad folded up at the lower end of the landing and a pad on top works well. 2-3 pads.
content.location: This is the first climb seen when walking downhill to the boulder. It is on the left side of the boulder, just to the left of "Private Label".

content.description: Sit start with both hands on the lip of the prow on a good Sloper. Move up right to a Gaston seam, then lefty to an edge before smacking direct for a slopey edge for the right hand. Once here figure out how to get the feet up and topout.This problem is a direct mantle to "Kaliedo Bioscience". It is slightly forced and definitely not as good as its neighbor.
content.location: The right side of the overhang. Starts on the lip of the arete/ prow and climbs direct.

content.description: Sit start the right arete/ prow feature with bith hands or just one hand on the obvious Sloper where the arete meets the lip. Pull on with some good feet and move rightwards using seams and slopers which lead to a powerful move to a large hold further right on the lip. From here figure out how to press it out and topout.
content.protection: 2-3 pads. The landing is fairly good but slightly uneven. One may have to stack a pad for the full sit due to the unevenness I the landing.
content.location: This problem is found on the far right side of the downhill overhanging face of the boulder and climbs rightwards along the lip.

content.description: Stand start the nice overhang on a crimp rail at about shoulder height. Power up to a good incut crimp, then smack up to a good sloper rail before smacking the giant sloping shell-shape bulge. Once here, a few hard moves over a high foot gain a giant jug!
content.protection: 2-5 pads. Crux may be the last move.
content.location: This problem is found on the large overhang that faces the stream.Â

content.description: Stand start the aesthetic overhang with a good left hand edge and another good edge a foot to the right. Pick a foot and power up to an edge straight up. From here utilize the shell like hold out left and a higher right hand hold before smacking a good sloper shelf for the left. From here gain some higher feet and enter crux territory trying to gain the topout jug.This problem starts just to the right of "General Dynamics". It climbs more direct whereas the mentioned climb moves left to the large sidepull feature. Most of the right hand holds for "General Dynamics" are used as left hand holds on this climb, but they seem to climb individually and uniquely and are about the same grade.
content.protection: 3-4 pads. The boulder is fairly exposed over the hillside but the landing is good.
content.location: The center of the downhill overhang.

content.description: A large block with two classics on a tall overhanging face.
